unnormalised: Alright folks, let's talk about kids! Specifically, a few things I've learned about pediatrics that I wish I knew sooner. As parents, we're constantly Googling symptoms and worrying about every little sniffle. I hope this post helps you navigate the wonderful, albeit sometimes stressful, world of kiddo health.

unnormalised: Firstly, don't underestimate the power of a good pediatrician. Dr. Sharma at Rainbow Children's Hospital is a lifesaver. Seriously. She's seen my little Rohan through everything from chickenpox to a mysterious rash that turned out to be nothing more than a mild allergic reaction. Finding a pediatrician you trust is half the battle won. I initially met with 3 different peds before I made my choice.

unnormalised: Speaking of chickenpox, vaccinations are KEY! I know there's a lot of debate surrounding them, but honestly, the peace of mind is worth it. Rohan got his MMR vaccine at 15 months, as per the schedule Dr. Sharma recommended. And guess what? No measles, mumps, or rubella. Phew! It also saves you a trip to the emergency room at 2 AM with a screaming, feverish child.
normalised: Speaking of chickenpox, vaccinations are K-E-Y! I know there's a lot of debate surrounding them, but honestly, the peace of mind is worth it. Rohan got his M-M-R vaccine at fifteen months, as per the schedule Doctor Sharma recommended. And guess what? No measles, mumps, or rubella. Phew! It also saves you a trip to the emergency room at two A-M with a screaming, feverish child.

unnormalised: One thing that caught me off guard was how quickly kids get sick, especially when they start going to playschool. Suddenly, it’s a constant cycle of colds and coughs. We went through a particularly rough patch last winter. He was down with a fever of 102°F on 12/25/2023. It was Christmas day! Talk about bad timing.

We went through a particularly rough patch last winter. He was down with a fever of one hundred and two degree Fahrenheit on twenty fifth december two thousand and twenty three. It was Christmas day! Talk about bad timing.

unnormalised: Then there are the dreaded ear infections. Rohan had 2 of them before he turned 3. Those were rough, poor baby. We learned that often, it clears up on its own, but sometimes antibiotics are necessary. Dr. Sharma prescribed Amoxicillin 250mg/5ml, twice a day for 7 days. Always, always follow your doctor's instructions, folks!

unnormalised: Fevers can be terrifying, but remember, they're often a sign that the body is fighting something off. Don't panic at the first sign of a raised temperature. Keep an eye on your little one, make sure they're hydrated, and if the fever goes above 103°F or lasts for more than 24 hrs, then give the doctor a call.
normalised: Fevers can be terrifying, but remember, they're often a sign that the body is fighting something off. Don't panic at the first sign of a raised temperature. Keep an eye on your little one, make sure they're hydrated, and if the fever goes above one hundred and three degree Fahrenheit or lasts for more than twenty four hours, then give the doctor a call.

unnormalised: Pro tip: Learn basic first aid for kids. Knowing how to handle minor cuts, burns, and choking hazards can be incredibly helpful in those frantic moments. There are plenty of online resources and local workshops that teach these essential skills. My wife and I took a course at the local Red Cross chapter - best decision ever!

unnormalised: Food allergies are another common concern. Introducing new foods can be nerve-wracking. Always introduce new foods one at a time and watch for any reactions. Rohan is allergic to peanuts (we found out during his 1st birthday party, not fun), so we always carry an EpiPen just in case. It's better to be safe than sorry.

unnormalised: Don't be afraid to ask questions! No question is too silly when it comes to your child's health. Write down your concerns before your appointment so you don't forget anything. Dr. Sharma always says, "There are no stupid questions, only unasked ones."

unnormalised: And finally, remember that every child is different. What works for one kid may not work for another. Trust your instincts, listen to your pediatrician, and don't compare your child to others. Enjoy those precious moments, even the ones filled with sniffles and sleepless nights. They grow up way too fast.
